commitResults.messageTitle: Renamed bot, created intro + exit message

commitResults.messageBody:
Fixed bug from level 3 where you could not enter jobs that were longer than one word.

Implemented task functionality necessary for level 4

commitResults.messageTitle: Implemented test case, minor changes to appearance
Created Yapchit exception classes, implemented exception handling
Implemented delete, refactored if statements to switch statements
created function to handle import from file
Implement date object functionality in deadline
commitResults.messageBody: Implemented functionality to handle dates provided with deadlines as a date object rather than as Strings, improving flexibility.
Created an initial split of Yapchit class into multiple classes. Finished implementation of TaskList, Handler, Parser classes.

Finished implementation of more OOP. Split Yapchit class into 5 other classes, each handling a different function.

- Yapchit: Main Yapchit class, encapsulates the entire bot.
- Handler: Contains primary functionality to handle operations and requests. Acts as the 'brains'
- Parser: Parses input
- Ui: Deals with accepting user input and various forms of output (printing) on the screen
- TaskList: Encapsulates the list of tasks and performs list operations.
- Storage: Deals with the storage and retrieval of tasks to/from the computer's memory.
Created a Yapchit package to encompass codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: Create HandlerTest file along with testcases
commitResults.messageBody: Created a new class called HandlerTest that contains comprehensive testcases to test the handleDeadline method in the handler class.

commitResults.messageTitle: Create ParserTest file along with testcases
commitResults.messageBody: Created a new class called PaserTest that contains comprehensive testcases to test the parseInput method in the parser class.

Implemented the ability to find tasks based on a search term.
Modified printList feature to accommodate this functionality.
Made minor fixes throughout the program to improve coding standard
Added JavaDocs for improved readability of code.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update handling of missing file error
Include assertions at key parts of the code
commitResults.messageBody:
Include assertions at key parts of the code

The current code lacks assertions at relevant spots.

Assertions are important to ensure that bugs in the code are caught
before they cause worse problems.

Including assertions at relevant spots in the code, primarily the
Handler class and the Yapchitbackend class ensures:
* safe transfer of data between different components of Yapchit
* more bugs that can cause errors down the line are caught early

As the Handler class and Yapchitbackend primarily facilitate
this communication between components it is important to
at least include assertions there.
Include assertions at key parts of the code

This reverts commit 9b12cec69ec44e8feac5bceceb4aa9d676cf556b, reversing
changes made to 997f76effe36fe518adc4f67634edeae246e64f8.

Code Quality Improvement: Enhance readability, reduce unsafe practices

Yapchit, Handler, Yapchitbackend classes (primarily) have code that
it not compliant with code quality rules, such as functions with common
behaviours, recycled parameters, and large methods etc.

These aspects of the code hinder readability while also making the
code more bug prone.

Key approaches taken to solve the issues:
* Wherever possible and reasonably impactful, common behaviour was
  abstracted out into a separate method.
* New variables were introduced to eliminate recycling of parameters
* Large methods were split into smaller ones.
* Variables were brought closer to the scope in which they are used
Most of the improvements were in the Handler class and the Yapchit
class.

These methods were adopted because they allowed the code to fit
the code quality requirements as outline by the textbook. They are
also typical practice when it comes to addressing similar problems
(i.e. abstraction etc.)
Improve code quality

Include more asserations

While current code has some assertions
more help to ensure more bugs are caught.

Assertions were inserted at prominent locations
in yapchitbackend, storage and other classes where
there were sensitive processes taking place and
interchange of data.

Such places are where bugs can occur, especially if
there is transfer between two classes. Often times
when writing the code, the two classes were written
in different times of the day or different days, hence
potential for error and bugs is higher.

This fixes issues relating to commits

I originally created a commit with assertions. However, I
merged the PR early, so I undid the changes in the
commit. However, when I fixed it and went to create
the PR at the correct time, the changes I had initially
merger were not reflected in the PR, but were on the
branch.

This commit fixes that issue by editing each of the
original assertions slightly

This is so that git recognises it as a new change and
hence registers them in the new PR.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/yapchit/yapchitbackend/Handler.java
#	src/main/java/yapchit/yapchitbackend/Storage.java
#	src/main/java/yapchit/yapchitbackend/YapchitBackend.java
#	src/main/java/yapchit/yapchitui/Yapchit.java
Branch a assertions

Implement ability to update tasks

Currently tasks cannot be edited once created

This limits functionality of the bot as editing
tasks is a natural thing to do.

Including and handling an update keyword
allows people to use this function.

The keyword is necessary to inform that this is
a new function. It also enables seamless
incorporation along with the existing commands

Update format is:
update [task index] [new name] [/param] [new param]
If a parameter or the name is not being updated,
you may use the '*' to notify the program that
you wish to keep the existing value.

Consequently, '*' is now a reserved character and cannot
be used like a typical one. This decision limits inputs
slightly but the decision was made because it is unlikely
that a user will enter just a '*' as a name or description
to any task.

Examples of update commands:
 - update 1 eat /by 2020-11-11
 - update 4 say hello
 - update 2 * /from * /to tomorrow
Implement task update functionality
